Name: They Were Soldiers
Description:
The game is a turn-based operational level 2-player contest based on the battle for LZ X-Ray during the larger "Battle of the Ia Drang Valley" in Vietnam, 1965. There was a successful movie starring Mel Gibson made about this well-known battle for the Landing Zone.  The game is challenging for both sides and historically accurate, but only takes a few hours and can be played at one sitting.

They Were Soldiers: Battle of the Ia Drang Valley lasts 15 turns. Each turn, players alternate moving and attacking each other’s forces on the game map, which is divided into hexes. Combat can include small arms firefights between adjacent units or fire missions that target hexes with artillery, airstrikes, helicopter gunships and mortars.

At the end of the combat phase, once all fire combat is complete, adjacent units may conduct close quarters combat (CQC) to decide which force will occupy contested hexes.

Each turn, after all movement and combat is completed, both sides draw cards to determine special actions for the future turns and may get reinforcements according to a preset schedule based on the history of the battle.

History - At 10:48 A.M. on the morning of November 14th, 1965, the first 80 soldiers of the 1st Battalion of the U.S. 7th Cavalry landed in a small clearing at the foot of the Chu Pong Massif in central Vietnam near the Cambodian border.  The Americans had landed in the middle of the base area for an entire North Vietnamese division, and were almost immediately attacked from multiple sides of their small landing zone - called ‘LZ X-Ray’.

The battle raged over the next several days, with high losses on both sides.  In the end, the Americans had proved their new airmobility tactics and had inflicted high losses on the North Vietnamese Army (NVA) soldiers they faced.  The NVA had also learned how to fight the Americans - and had inflicted serious losses on a high-tech superpower enemy  by using classic light infantry tactics with only a fraction of the firepower available to the Americans.

This game challenges the players to re-fight the first day or so of that battle - the critical time when the NVA forces had the chance to overwhelm the Americans and overrun the landing zone.  Can you, as the U.S. player, hold your ground and repeat history?  Or will the NVA player triumph and overwhelm the perimeter - cutting the Americans off from supply and reinforcement?  Get ready to re-live or re-write history in the battle for LZ-Xray!
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: PanzerBlitz Minigame
Description: This is a minigame of tactical armor and infantry combat in Russia during WWII. Essentially a one-scenario demo, PanzerBlitz Minigame uses the game system developed in SPI's TAC Game 3 and refined for PanzerBlitz (a design sold to and published by Avalon Hill). PanzerBlitz Minigame was published in Strategy & Tactics 22 and uses the mapsheet for the main game published in that issue, Renaissance of Infantry: Tactical Warfare, 1250 A.D-1550 A.D (which dealt with tactical warfare between 1250 A.D. and 1550 A.D.). In addition to the rules folder and mapsheet, there were 60 counters (30 German, 30 Russian).
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Hedge Mazers
Description:
You all are world renowned Hedge Maze designers. You are trying to have your design chosen by the Elitist of Elites to have your Hedge Maze used at their new vacation home.

Everybody is given a player board with a cover so that your design is kept secretive. There is a draw bag where X amount of Hedge pieces are in the bag. Every round 5 pieces are drawn from the bag and placed in the center of the table. Starting with the 1st player of that turn you will select a tile from the center followed by everyone else. Once everyone has placed the tile on their player board it remains there and can not be moved. 1st player token is passed to the next player and the round repeats until there are only 4 pieces in the center in which end game is triggered. This will be the last piece placed on the board and the game is over. Time to score.

Victory points will include different objectives that will be met as a whole and individual objectives as well. Most Dead Ends. Most Turns. Shortest distances from start to finish. Longest distances from start to finish.
Certain tiles may be worth certain points as well. Say if they are harder to place tiles and only limited to one or two in the bag.

-description from designer

Name: Just One: Neue Begriffe
Description: In case you have played the 2019 Spiel des Jahres-winning Just One more times than you can recall and have already memorized all the words in the base game, the Just One: Neue Begriffe expansion pack includes more than five hundred new terms to guess, in addition to two more player easels so that you can have up to nine players in the game.
Families: Components: Dry Erase Markers / Dry Erase Surfaces

Name: Flagment Dig Rayn
Description:
Flagment Dig Rayn is a doujin trading card game designed by doujin group Eternity Satellite.
In this game, playes fight with the opponent using a deck of cards and a leader card out of the deck. The goal of the game is to defeat the opponent's leader.
Unlike most trading card games, this game has a board with 19 hexagons, in which characters can move, and each character has a attack range.

Name: Carnival of Monsters: Phoenix
Description:
Promo Monster card for Carnival of Monsters.
Issued with Plato Magazine #125 (April/May 2020).

Phoenix
level 2
Aerie Land
1 Danger
8 VP

Name: Xmas Sweater
Description:
In Xmas Sweater, each player “knits” their own Christmas sweaters by filling the spaces on their “sweater” with numbers.
 Players all play at the same time, with everyone trying to fill the rows on their scoresheets with numbers as high as possible in order to score the most points.

To play, you will need three D12 (1 red, 1 green, and 1 white) and one black D6, one printed scoresheet for each player as well as a pencil or pen.

â— On a turn, one player rolls the four dice into the middle of the play area.

â— Each player chooses one D12 (without picking it up) and writes the value in any space that matches the color of that D12. Multiple players may choose the same D12.

â— Once per round, players may use the Black D6 to modify the result of their chosen D12. (see "Modifying the Dice" in the rulebook). 
â—‹ The numbers in a row must remain in ascending order from left to right. (blank fields and the number 0 are okay)
â—‹ Number 0 can be written anywhere in the respective color.
(E.g.: The dice is rolled and there’s “5” with the red die and “5” with the black die, players can write “0” anywhere in either red row.).
â—‹ No duplicate numbers are allowed in any row or column. 
Number 0 is an exception to this rule.
â—‹ You may only write the values inside the icons (Hearts and Xmas Icons).

â— If the players can’t or won’t enter a number, they mark (X) the leftmost Gift Box on their scoresheet. These are considered as penalties.

When any player has all the Gift Boxes marked or has filled four rows on their scoresheet, the game ends at the end of that round. Players then tally their points:
â—‹ Each Fully Complete Row: 
Points equal to the number in the rightmost heart. 
â—‹ Each Incomplete Row: One point per entered number.
â—‹ Xmas Icons: Sum of the numbers in all three matching icons. 
(E.g.: A player has “18” in one of the trees, “2” in another trees, but he doesn’t have a number in the third tree, he scores “0”.)
(E.g.: A player has “4” in one of the hats, “10” in other hats and “6” in the third one, he scores “20”.)
â—‹ Gingerbread Man Bonus: If you managed to write the number “10” five times, you get +10 points.
â—‹ Each Gift Box: Sum of the marked points from left to right (max -30)

Whoever has the highest score wins. In case of tie, the player who has the least number of marked Gift Boxes wins the game. If there’s still a tie, the player who has the least empty hearts wins the game.

-description from designer

Name: BIRDIE!: Expansion Pack 1 – Järva DiscgolfPark & Ledgestone Eureka Lake
Description:
According to UDisc, there is one course rated higher than Maple Hill. That course is Jarva. We were really happy to be able to work with Jussi and Mats and the Jarva crew to get the stats and greens dialed in so the game plays correct to the real feel of the championship Jarva course.

Where Jarva adds a touch of classical challenge, Ledgestone's Eureka adds more strategy and decision making than we could have ever imagined. It also makes different players more powerful and different abilities and cards much more useful. It actually gives it the feel of the real pro tour in that, if you play with the same character across each of the courses, you will be faced with significantly different challenges. There is tons of OB. You've got to do some serious strategery to get through unscathed.

Name: Ways of Steel
Description:
In Ways of Steel, players represent owners of railway companies that manage to build stations, railways and of course, profit a lot from it. The game takes place in the United States in the middle of the 19th century, when the American government encourages private companies through tax incentives and letters of credit. The player who has the most victory points at the end of the game wins. Points are awarded for money, stations built, improvements to your railway company (wagons), hiring of specialists, accomplished objectives and government incentives (players who build more railways).

The game works with a different action selection mechanism, the actions are present in different wagons and the players are able to customize and improve this during the game. In addition to the wagons, the game always becomes different with the use of different specialists, objective cards and a customizable board.

—description from the designer

Name: Lustige Autofahrt mit Hindernissen
Description:
The players have to travel from start to finish to reach their vacation spot. The first to do so wins the game. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events benefit or hinder the players.

The game was published as the back of a blister pack or bag of 15 different lemonade powder items (Frigeo Brause Palette).

—user summary

Name: Würfelspiel Feueralarm
Description:
Six fires are put in any slots of the house. The remaining 6 fires are laid nearby as smoldering fires. The players in turn roll a die.
1-3: One fire is extinguished and placed in front of the player.
4: Nothing happens, all fires continue to burn.
5-6: A smoldering fire is placed into a slot in the house.

If all fires are extinguished before all smoldering fires broke out, the player who has extinguished the most fires wins the game.

If all smoldering fires have broken out and at least one fire burns at the end of the round, the house burns down and all players have lost.

This game was published as a cut-out sheet.

—user summary

Name: Immer auf Tuchfühlung
Description:
Each player has 10 pawns, he has to get from his side on the game board to the opposite side. Two pawns of the same color may occupy the same space. Movement is one space diagonally forward on the red spaces. Only single pawns of another color may be caught by jumping (diagonally forward)over the pawn on a free space behind it.

The pawns have to move in groups of at least four pawns on adjacent spaces. If one or more pawns get separated from their group, they are eliminated from the game.

If a pawn gets separated by catching another pawn, the player has to connect this pawn to a group in the next two turns or the pawn is lost.

The player who gets the most pawns to the opposite side wins the game.

—user summary

Name: Die Urzeit Horde
Description:
The players have to get their one or three pawns (cavemen) from start to finish. The first to do so wins the game. Movement is determined by a die. On the red spaces events hinder or benefit the players. If a player gets on a space with dice eyes, he may not move till he rolls the indicated number.

—user summary

Name: Congeria
Description:
Congeria is a game where you decide how good or bad you want to play it. It's a card game where each player has their own goal to acquire 5 different colored gems. To acquire them, players take cards from decks in the middle that allow them to take gems from various locations. Either nicely from the communal pool or not so nicely from other players. First player to reach their goal wins.

—description from the designer

Name: Enigma, Intriga y Misterio
Description:
A quick game of intrigue and mystery that challenges your power of observation. You are the detective in a hotel that will accompany people who take the elevator. But be careful because it is very easy to lose sight of them, as they seem to disappear before your eyes.

This is a game that takes place in an old European hotel. People move from floor to floor in a fascinating elevator that contains open compartments, moving in an endless chain. They enter one of the compartments while moving up and down, and then get off on another floor. Your job as a hotel detective is to follow the trail of all the mysterious characters using the elevator. Both the compartments and the characters are in constant motion, so you must use memory and logic to locate them all.

Object of the game: the 9 cards are placed face down on the table in two rows, in order to represent the elevator. A different character is shown in each compartment, they are in constant movement.
Players will try to be the first to guess the position of all the characters on the moving elevator cards, matching them (pair up) with the character cards in their hands.

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Imperial Armour – Apocalypse
Description:
Imperial Armour Apocalypse is a book produced by Forge World related to Warhammer 40,000 Apocalypse. Within it are rules for the use of many of the models produced by forgeworld in Apocalypse games.

The book has 112 pages and the cover and contents are printed in colour.

This book serves three purposes. First, it provides rules for Imperial Armour models. The arrival of Apocalypse has made it necessary to update the rules for some of our models, which were previously published in our large Imperial Armour volumes and Update books. In fact this book now replaces the Imperial Armour Update 2006. Rules changes are especially important for super-heavy vehicles, aircraft and gargantuan creatures. All of these troop types have new rules in Apocalypse rulebook and obviously our rules needed to fit with these. Secondly, Apocalypse has introduced several new blast marker templates, which did not exist when our original rules were published. Where appropriate we have used these new templates for our models (for example, the Manticore). Thirdly, we have incorporate many Imperial Amour models into new battle formations. All straight forward enough... or is it? The arrival of Apocalypse provides players with a perfect arena in which to use their Imperial Armour models, and as such serves as an examples of how these models can be used in different styles of Warhammer 40,000 games.

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Imperial Armour – Apocalypse II
Description:
Imperial Armour - Apocalypse II is a supplement for the Warhammer 40,000 expansion Apocalypse. It provides updated rules for numerous Forge World miniatures and a few missions to play.

Five different missions for use in Apocalypse games:
The Killing Ground
The Bloody Last Stand
Line Breaker
Rolling Thunder
A Clash of Titans

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Imperial Armour – Apocalypse Second Edition
Description:
Imperial Armour - Apocalypse Second Edition is a book published by Forge World to replace Imperial Armour - Apocalypse. It contains updated and brand new rules for using Forge World's models in games of Warhammer 40,000 and Apocalypse, as well as three new Apocalypse missions.

The book has 128 pages and is printed in colour.

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Imperial Armour – Apocalypse
Description:
Imperial Armour - Apocalypse (2013) is a book published by Forge World to replace Imperial Armour - Apocalypse Second Edition. It contains updated and brand new rules for using Forge World's models in games of Warhammer 40,000 and Apocalypse.

The book has 170 pages and is printed in colour.

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Imperial Armour – Aeronautica
Description: Imperial Armour Aeronautica is a Forge World supplement book for Warhammer 40,000 that contains 6th Edition rules for 34 flyers and 13 anti-aircraft units fielded by the Imperial Navy, Space Marines, Orks, Eldar, Tyranids, Tau Empire, Necrons, Dark Eldar and Chaos. Also included are the wargear and special rules unique to the aircraft of the 41st Millennium. It also features a narrative campaign, the Scourging of Kerrack, which provides six Warhammer 40,000 missions. The book is concluded by an Apocalypse rules appendix, updated for the 6th edition of Warhammer 40,000

Name: Never Mind the Billhooks
Description:
Never mind the Billhooks is set at the Big Skirmish/Small battle level, the sort of thing that probably went on a lot of the time, particularly up around the Scottish borders, without ever troubling the chroniclers. 
My original inspiration was Nibley Green, Gloucestershire, fought in 1470 between the private armies of Lords Lisle and Berkeley, with no more than 1,000 men a side.

Billhooks is a card-activated game with points-based random army generation and using only good old D6s. 
You roll dice to hit and dice to save (depending on armour) so it’s very familiar Old School in that respect. 
Longbows are deadly but not dominant since their arrow supply is limited, so to win a battle you have to get stuck into Melee. 
Cavalry and skirmishers have their uses but it’s the heavy infantry – Men at Arms, Bills and Pikes – who will win the battle for you.

All the key rules are on a short Cribsheet (with no confusing tables of plusses and minuses) and you should find yourself playing along without too much reference to the main rules after only a few turns. A typical two-player game with about 100 figures a side will play out in 1 to 1 ½ hours but it will easily expand to a bigger, multi-player set-up once everyone is familiar with the common and easily-memorized mechanisms.

—description from the designer at WI
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players
